bibl.title: Letter from Henry Hanson to Henry Rose Carter, March 17, 1921

div1.p: Hanson reports on a yellow fever epidemic in Peru. The local newspaper is publishing articles denouncing his sanitary campaign.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Hanson to Henry Rose Carter, March 17, 1921
div1.opener:
DIRECCION
DE LA
CAMPAÑA SANITARIA
CONTRA LA FIEBRE AMARILLA
EN LOS DEPARTAMENTOS DEL NORTE
____
OFICINA CENTRAL
Report
Hanson
Chiclayo March 17, 1921.
Dr. H.R. Carter,
Asst Surgeon General, U.S.P.H.S.,
Wahington, D.C.
My Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
I am addressing you at Washington as I forget
to ask you where your addres would be but am sure that you will get
your maik in this manner.

I am very busy rearranging the office and getting a lineup
on the distribution of the forces. I hope by the end of this week that
I will have things running on a more efficient basis. There has been
considerable lack of judgement in the distribution of the forces.
The work itself has been fairly well done as the stegomyia index is
very considerably reduced. In Chiclayo it seems to be down to about
5% at the present time, and there are very few cases which can be
charged up to Chiclayo itself. However we have several cases on hand
now. I have done two autopsies since arriving. One a case which died
in the forth day of illness and the other after six days, both of
which gave sufficient post mortem evidence.

The epidemic is spreading east and south, and I am rather
worried, especially because I listened to Quiroz when we left, and
did not take Mendoza with us at the time. I have practically certain
evidence that the epidemic is in Cayaltí and Saña. I have sent
Quiroz there to investigate. The old Doctor there has made several
diagnoses of “fiebre biliosa hemoglobinurica” which to me means noth-
ing less than yellow fever. More he has treated several of these
cases with hypos of quinine with the result that those so treated
have promptly turned over and died. Yellow fever has also appeared
in Chongoyape, which is due east from here, but of very little im-
portance as far as Libertad is concerned.

Mendoza and Sainz are still waiting in the port of Pimentel
for steamer to go south. It is most fortunate that I did not go on
to Paita, because I probably should not have been back yet.

Valdevieso reports that he has commenced work in Guadelupe
and Chepén. Dr. Cavassa of Guadelupe also reports activity, and I
hope they make it very active. Benites has been ordered to Pacasmayo
and Reyes to Cayaltí for the time being. I think I will transfer himo
Pacasmayo as soon as the other two inspectors arrive from Piura. I
Have also called Juan E. Adrienzen and Joaquin Castillo. I think it
would be a very good thing to have one or possibly two of the Canal
Inspectors, or men with equal aptitude for learning this line of work

The daily, “El Pais” is carrying on a most vicious propaganda
against the sanitary campaign. For sensible people it should be with-
out effect. Unfortunately here there are a lot of people who follow
these ridiculous articles like a dog in a leash, and make things
decidedly difficult for the Doctors and the Inspectors and Visitadors

I have been very well impressed with some of the local men who
are working here. With proper supervision I think we have the material
for developing several very good men here and hope in the final peri-
od of the campaign to have several dependable men with which to clean
up.

I think I will request the Prefecto to put a stop to the nonsene
in the newspapers.

Hoping that you are having a pleasant trip and that you are
better in health.
